subsection.title: Complex Eigenvalues
subsection.p: Notice that the solutions {\mathbf x}(t) = c_1 \begin{pmatrix} \cos \beta t \\ - \sin \beta t \end{pmatrix} + c_2 \begin{pmatrix} \sin \beta t\\ \cos \beta t \end{pmatrix} are periodic with period 2 \pi / \beta. This type of system is called a center.

example.p:
Consider the initial value problem
\frac{dx}{dt} \amp = 2y \frac{dy}{dt} \amp = -2x x(0) \amp = 1 y(0) \amp = 2.
The eigenvalues of this system are \lambda = \pm 2i. Therefore, the general solution to the system is
x(t) \amp = c_1 \cos 2t + c_2 \sin 2t y(t) \amp = - c_1 \sin 2t + c_2 \cos 2t.
Using the initial conditions to solve for c_1 and c_2, the solution to our initial value problem is
x(t) \amp = \cos 2t + 2 \sin 2t y(t) \amp = - \sin 2t + 2 \cos 2t.
The phase portrait is a circle of radius 2 about the origin ().

example.p:
The initial value problem
\frac{dx}{dt} \amp = x/10 + y \frac{dy}{dt} \amp = -x + y/10 x(0) \amp = 0 y(0) \amp = 1/2.
The matrix \begin{pmatrix} 1/10 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 1/10 \end{pmatrix} has an eigenvector (1, -i) with eigenvalue \lambda = 1/10 - i. Thus, the complex solution is \mathbf x(t) = e^{(1/10 - i)t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -i \end{pmatrix}. Following the procedure that we used in the previous example, the solution to our initial value problem is \mathbf x(t) = \frac{1}{2} e^{t/10} \begin{pmatrix} \sin t \\ \cos t \end{pmatrix}, and he phase portrait is a spiral source ().

subsection.title: Solving Systems with Complex Eigenvalues
subsection.p: Suppose that we have the linear system \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{pmatrix}. The charactistic polynomial of A is p(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - (a + d)\lambda + (ad - bc). If (a + d)^2 - 4(ad - bc) \lt 0, then the eigenvalues of A are complex, and we cannot apply the strategy that we used to determine the general solution in the case of distinct real roots.

The nature of the equilibrium solution is determined by the factor e^{\alpha t} in the solution. If \alpha \lt 0, the equilibrium point is a spiral sink. If \alpha \gt 0, the equilibrium point is a spiral source. If \alpha = 0, the equilibrium point is a center.

Although we have outlined a procedure to find the general solution of \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x if A has complex eigenvalues, we have not shown that this method will work in all cases. We will do so in .

statement.p: Consider the linear system d \mathbf x/dt = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp -1 \end{pmatrix}. Suppose the initial conditions for the solution curve are x(0) = 1 and y(0) = 1. We can use the following Sage code to plot the phase portrait of this system, including a solution curve.

sage.input: x, y, t = var('x y t') #declare the variables F = [3*x + 2*y, -3*x - y] #declare the system # normalize the vector fields so that all of the arrows are the same length n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) # plot the vector field p = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x, -30, 30), (y, -30, 30), aspect_ratio = 1) # solve the system for the initial condition t = 0, x = 1, y = 1 P1 = desolve_system_rk4(F, [x, y], ics=[0, 1, 1], ivar = t, end_points = 5, step = 0.01) # grab the x and y values S1 = [ [j, k] for i, j, k in P1] # plot the solution # Setting xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax will clip the window # Try plotting without doing this to see what happens p += line(S1, thickness = 2, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], xmin = -30, xmax = 30, ymin = -30, ymax = 30) p
